divs: Sighting DetailsI took my dog outside my house for his final relief at just before 10 o'clock PM as usual. I have been an amateur astronomer for about 50 years. I am a physicist and a surgeon. I noted the night sky. It was hazy but the big dipper and polaris were visible. At about 45 degrees above the horizon and due north I noted a 'point of light that I assumed to be a star' that brightened to about minus forth magnitude and was moving from its initial position at about 10 degrees east of polaris,in a strait line at a constant velocity towards the east about 45 degrees above the horizon. I estimate the altitude at above 30 thousand feet. As it traveled, it dimmed to a magnitude of less than 1.0 and it moved at a constant speed and heading. It disapeared as the sky 'clouded in' after traversing about 20 degrees with respect to my perspective in about 45 seconds...
Summary: a minus four magnitude flash that fadded away over minutes while moving
